title: Before 1 September 2022, will the World Trade Organization (WTO) officially agree to grant waivers for intellectual property protections for COVID-19 vaccine technology?
preds: Seems like there is a lot of noise about this actually getting done, I still have a very weak read on how plausible it actually is
Downgrading for lack of news pre-MC12

The lack of good news about WTO releasing waivers for the vaccine technology makes me revise my prediction from 15% down to 5%. A lack of public desire and lack of politicians willing to put weight on the issue makes it less and less likely, especially considering the September 1st deadline. At this point legal responses from COVID vaccine makers would draw it out past the deadline.
Haven't seen progress on any of the major issues facing this. Downgrading for the limited time until MC12.

I find it to be a low probability that the WTO would waive intellectual property protections for COVID-19 vaccine tech. It would require a black swan type event like an even more deadly virus, or something coming out to make current tech obsolete. Were this just about the Johnson and Johnson vaccine I would give it a higher probability due to that vaccines apparent weakness and higher rate of complications compared to the others.

The vaccines are manufactured by private, for-profit companies. The trend of private companies squeezing out every last penny of profit from any given venture in the face of morality is a notable trend, and I doubt that a crisis like COVID-19 will stop them from pressuring member states of the WTO from voting only on agreeable (and profitable) terms for IPP waivers regarding COVID-19 vaccine technology. Though the WTO meeting on May 6 went "well" regarding the waivers, it is made clear that there are still no agreeable terms; just no outright rejections among member states. Thus, based on prior trends regarding profitability of private business headquartered within powerful WTO member states (like Moderna and Pfizer), I find it highly unlikely that a finalized proposal is produced and favorably voted upon by 3/4ths consensus within the next few months.

As of this month (05/22) NYT has the world vaccinated population at roughly 67%. Profits from Moderna & Phizer have skyrocketed since COVID, and I wonder if they plan on milking every last dollar possible to get that last 1/3 of thee population vaccinated. My prediction, likely similar to many others, will be that these pharmaceutical giants will eventually waive their IP rights after the vaccinated population hovers at about 80-90% in a PR stunt to make themselves look favorable.

Upping my forecast thanks to great discussion @jleibowich and @MrLittleTexas here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1447908. Consensus will still be difficult, but the fact they've got a draft in front of them to negotiate makes a big difference. Realistically, the only chance for the TRIPS waiver to go ahead before September is at MC12 in June (if it actually goes ahead this time).

Using Bayes, I had no probability last week so my Prior started with an estimate of 50%. There are 164 WTO members and 75% need to approve any TRIPS waiver which means 123 members must approve. Several articles indicate that there are over 100 members who currently back the proposal, which includes the US. Prior to last week, there were at least 29 countries (UK/Switzerland/EU) that dissented on this topic. Last week a draft document from the negotiation among the Quad members who previously dissented on the TRIPS waiver was released for all to review prior to the upcoming WTO meeting in June. A few issues still remain to be resolved though my estimate is that the fact that they released the draft assigns an 80% favorable probability that the TRIPS waiver will be passed with enough support of those mentioned and those not factored for. I think there is still a 30% chance that the dissenting countries will end up dissenting to stand in solidarity with core IP rules. By Bayesian statistics, I obtain a 73% probability that the TRIPS waiver will be granted by the WTO on the timeline indicated.

https://www.bnnbloomberg.ca/china-rejects-its-exclusion-from-wto-vaccine-waiver-proposal-1.1762407There is a concerted effort to get it done, but seems like a time crunch is approaching and a lot of nations still opposed (China, UK, Switzerland)
Will become less and less of an issue as time passes. Somewhat fat tail however with the possibility of a new strain bringing the issue back to the fore.
It will become less and less of an issue over the course of the year.

https://www.reuters.com/business/healthcare-pharmaceuticals/last-few-tweaks-being-made-covid-ip-waiver-deal-wto-chief-2022-04-14/
Just a couple more tweaks, then 164 states have to give it the okey-dokey.  Some of them are already displeased with Our Story So Far.  Going from 0 to 4, but no more until the tweakmeisters have something to say, and probably no big change then, either.

Decay off initial news a compromise had been reached - some countries are still pushing to get more in a deal, but the BATNA is squarely with the veto players, so we will see what backroom deals lead to. Still plenty of time before September, so giving myself a cushion to decay further if necessary.
now it is seen to late
First I do not believe that they legally can, secondly that would jeopardize the entire patenting reasoning and thirdly there are too many interest groups against it.

Going down based on statements at the ended EU Africa summit. Even if it would help cement her image as the "geopolitical commission" President, and support other horizontal EC policies such as Global Gateway, vdL seems inherently opposed to waivers. With omicron and states relaxing measures, the global South may be the final "hope" for companies to capitalize on the tech, but as per previous rationale, may lead to the complete opposite effect, so not going to 0.
Unless a new absorber emerges, there seems to be no need as omicron it's less deadly and life is returning to pre-covid state gradually

there is a lot of pressure on vaccine manufacturers to give up their IPR. In addition, waiving the IPR would not necessarily mean that other companies can start producing mRNA vaccines so easily, limiting the impact on owners of IP. On the other hand, Companies with IPR have private interests to defend
IP and financial interests of the private sector
Both WTO is rather weakened and the mRNA technology is very promising for other applications.

The negotiations are in deadlock for quite a while without a clear sign of possible improvement in the near future. The EU Member States (among top contributors to the WTO budget) haven't agreed yet on a joint position towards possible IPR waivers.
Quite unlikely as this would impact the whole innovation system fundamentally, quite some member states will vote against

A new outbreak from a low vaccine area/country, of a variant with greater than Omicron level contagion and much higher mortality rate, spread heavily in a world that wants to be "post Covid" and so lax/tired of restrictions will push the WTO to drop IP protections as part of a "rapid response" to the new outbreak.

While inventory by Human Rights Watch has identified capacity for production of RNA-vaccines in many countries, lack of infrastructure and sophisticated production capacity in developing countries is often used as an argument to resist patent waiver. Corporate interest will prevail and lobby against EU to agree waiver unless new surprises in terms of new and possibly more lethal variants. WTO decisions against EU is unlikely.
https://www.hrw.org/news/2021/12/15/experts-identify-100-plus-firms-make-covid-19-mrna-vaccines

Unlikely: the vaccine has shown political competition between WTO member states had influence on which vaccine was bought and distributed, with China and Russia having their own vaccines and actively combating the distribution of Western vaccines. As such, and in the framework of international tensions around Ukraine, the politicall disputes around it could lead to refusal by one party or the other to allow IP waivers

Rather than the patent enforcablity or the coverage.
Weighing the wavier against the percentage of fully vaccinated in low income countries might be a good measure.
I will try to use Africa as the reference which is at 11% and when this reaches 50% assume no pressure to wavier IP from the WTO. https://ourworldindata.org/covid-vaccinations

Vaccine producers or rather their inventors have negotiated with various local governments, right now the outcome seems very unlikely since especially MRNA technology can bring many other medical innovations / new drugs.

As pointed out in the above mentioned CNN article experts say it could take months if not years to build out the infrastructure to manufacture Vaccine in developing countries. Because of this I don’t believe that European countries will agree to suspend intellectual property rights.

- According to https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2022/1/11/new-email-piles-more-pressure-on-uk-pm-johnson-over-lockdown-parties, WHO sees new vaccins as more probable, which needs innovation.
- According to https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20220123-europe-could-be-headed-for-pandemic-endgame-who (even though stated about Europe), WHO sees Omicron as reducing COVID risk considerabley Both make the pressure for a patent waiver lower.

I don't believe that this action would help, considering that the downstream network is now the more difficult problem to manage, and there is already plenty of Astra vaccine available at 'cost'. There will also be regular vaccine 'tweaks' attempting to cope with the next variants, which will put a question mark on long-term vaccine shelf life. With that said, I'm sure there are many companies in the vaccine development race who would benefit from IP de-regulation, as would 3rd world countries who struggle to distribute the vaccines that they may have access to. Any new 'entrant'  would still have to go through the normal regulatory approval machinery, which is closely monitored by the incumbent producers.
https://www.bmj.com/content/372/bmj.n281#:~:text=The%20Oxford%2DAstraZeneca%20vaccine%20is,%244%2C%20respectively%2C%20per%20dose.
No need for this action, licensing can be arranged
Countries such as Germany which stand to lose from this deal will try and block this from happening
I don't think waiving IP protections actually solves any of the production/distribution problems, plus heavy hand of pharma to deal with

There is at least one case in which WTO waivers were released, which at least shows there is a possibility. Countries like China, US and India have expressed support, it seems to me that the opposers (EU, GB, Switzerland) are increasingly isolated. Yet on the other hand the US has also not put in the effort it could have to work around these patents, which might show a lack of motivation to push against the opposers. In the end the chance that waivers will be agreed might still be relatively small, I think there’s a bigger chance than the current consensus estimates. https://www.asil.org/insights/volume/11/issue/28/canadian-made-drugs-rwanda-first-application-wto-waiver-patents-and
https://www.theregreview.org/2022/01/13/khodor-support-waiver-covid-19-vaccine-patents/
As Covid becomes endemic and seem less of an emergency profit will prevail.
Big pharma lobbying is too powerful to allow this.   Nations have cooperated little during the pandemic.

First guess.
If the current situation persists and vaccination of developing countries do not increase significantly there might be more pressure to grant waivers.
I will try to improve the predictions as I learn more about the topic.

ip protections are the lifeblood of biomedical companies. To deny them this time would invite many challenges in the future between governments and these companies during other pandemics and outbreaks
There are new vaccines that are aimed to assist them developing world. They are less complicated to make and store
Patents are the rightful merit for developing vaccines. Therefore, the Western governments will not change this.
No. There is no need for that.

One understands the impulse and rarely agrees with the Big Pharma posse, but in this case there is a strong case to be made about the deterrent effect on research if IP protection is, shall we say, attenuated.  (There is a bad gag available here anent "attenuating circumstances," but I'll leave it for someone else.)

Relevant points from https://www.reuters.com/business/healthcare-pharmaceuticals/exclusive-wto-chief-says-vaccine-answer-close-facing-effort-block-it-2021-12-16/: - "Discussions ... have been deadlocked for more than a year" -- I don't see anything convincing that would change this
- "developed members ... argue it would be better to use existing WTO rules" -- apparently, there are existing alternatives, also speaks against waivers

The virus is evolving into a seasonal one, with a lower death rate. This is the most important factor. 
Vaccines might not be the only medical treatment we will be using against SARS2 or COVID-19. Researchers are working on new drugs or checking if the old one helps with severe cases.
This would be a "dangerous" example for other IP/patents waiver cases, e.g. medicine for COVID-19, so business and medical companies won't be in favour.
So the efforts on the WTO forum might not be successful.

My belief about COVID-19's near future is here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1378546 I think that it will increase steeply in January and reach a peak mid January and begin falling steeply as well. Then cases will be low until the end of 2022. If this is the case, pressure to approve the vaccine will subside.  3/4 of 164 is 123. The article by US News & World Report above indicates that 100 were willing. But if it didn't happen in May of 2021, I don't think it is going to happen this year. Too many holdouts but not impossible.
Governments will placate pharma companies with cash
Govts will assuage companies through promise of low price supply to exposed countries to eliminate need for IP waivers. Dangerous precedent otherwise from view of big pharma

Till Covid and Variants will spread, assuming Omicron to be the last and endemic one "hopefully", there are still too many financial interests behind this kind of bsnss.
Also taking into consideration Thermal Stable Vaccine to come.

The question is about the possible agreement between countries (by October there was already a consensus of 50% and growing), not about whether companies are going to object to the decision or get the WTO to soften the initial agreement (as in the case of HIV). Maybe I am too optimistic, but apart from that, other elements in favor are: 1. Over three-quarters of WTO members are developing countries and countries in transition to market economies
2. Doha Declaration: "4. The TRIPS Agreement does not and should not prevent Members from taking measures to protect public health
3. The pressure caused by Omicron, and COVID becoming endemic
4. HIV/AIDS TRIPS past experience
5. They can always reach an agreement on an amendment to an agreement

Major drug companies and certain countries are against this making it unlikely, and perhaps some alternate route will be explored (see sources). Though, there is a chance that overall public health concerns in light of Omicron prevail.  Sources:
https://sdg.iisd.org/commentary/policy-briefs/as-vaccine-roll-out-begins-wto-members-intensify-debate-over-policy-solutions/
https://www.reuters.com/business/healthcare-pharmaceuticals/exclusive-wto-chief-says-vaccine-answer-close-facing-effort-block-it-2021-12-16/

Doubt it, if for no other reason than major vaccine producing countries are against it.  (Of course, China likes it since it will afford them technology know how since the patent itself is of limited value.  It is the mRNA manufacturing technology itself that is valuable and would need to be relinquished to product it ... the future of Moderna and BioNTech rests adaptation of mRNA technology for other drug applications, diseases.)  The other factor is there is now a successful vaccine relying proven technology and not requiring uber cold storage that is being licensed without monetary payment ... Corbevax.
the WTO needs every member to agree I think that is extraordinary unlikely

The real barrier is not specific to Covid, but the future ability to make vaccines for other diseases. The technical infrastructure is too valuable to let go. Additionally, it will be complicated to work out export controls on the technology that would be enforceable. As Covid shifts towards endemic status, the specific merit of any specific vaccine “product” will fall. The utility of an agreement is falling fast.

It is likely that the influential governments will choose to protect their industries. However their might be increase pledges to support vaccine exports to or Joint ventures in developing countries depending on the developing situation with COVID.
the lobbyists for those rich drug companies will prevail at the WTO. also it goes against their patent rules to do this.

This question is effectively asking whether or not we live in a world governed by common sense, where collective action for the greater good is possible. In the current globalized geopolitical environment, massive profits for the few will always be prioritized above everything else. Obviously. “Nobody is safe until everyone is safe” is not a winning argument. Only a major political upheaval in member countries could improve the chances for waivers, and the chance of that is far too small to represent.
It’s very unlikely that the companies and countries that have invested and supported investments in IP will grant waivers
Deaths will rise in the developing world
Given the outbreak of new variants, I think the WTO and member states will be wary of undermining the incentives for companies to continue to invest in vaccines to treat these new variants.

Would have gone for a lower probability (~5%) on this one but for the US backing for the waivers provided by Biden in Nov.
Still see the opposition from developed European countries being a blocker, even with US pressure.
No. the pharma industry holds a lot of influence in the US

3/4 of member states is a high bar, there are lots of vaccine available, problems are not on the subject of supply but demand, logistics to provide vaccine, etc. Plus there seems to be a new vaccine offered with free licensing. This is more a subject for activists but the need is limited, we are not in the same situation as aids. China also is still a huge vaccine provider and is quite silent on this idea.
If there is a global campaign in favour of it with european countries and the US moving all in this direction I would revise my judgment.

Given the revised US position in favour of TRIPS waivers [1], I would not rule this out completely. However, the European Commission seems more interested in focusing on vaccine donations, and keeps shifting the focus away from IP bottlenecks. While there is a small level of public pressure in the EU, I cannot think of a scenario where it sharply rises two years into the pandemic.  There will be even less will to establish further precedent for TRIPS waivers if omicron is seen - as it increasingly is by European politicians - as the "high transmissibility/low severity" variant. European WTO delegates will not make it a consensus vote, and the price/benefit ration for rocking the boat will keep worsening for those who would hope to get a 3/4ths vote. If pharmaceutical companies continue investing into their COVID-19 IP - like updating to account for new variants [2] [3] - they will continue lobbying as severely as thus far to guarantee a return on those investments and not endanger future opportunities. One alternative scenario could be one where precisely a lower risk assessment of omicron combined with rapid development of antivirals [4] sees European countries shift to a strategy of managing COVID-19 with therapeutics rather than successive booster shots, which are much less popular with their citizens. In such a scenario, TRIPS waivers for vaccines could be seen as a good faith engagement - though the question remains of just how much potential pharmaceutical companies will see in a "captive" market in low-vaccination-rate countries. Also, this hinges on a majority of the big players releasing approved therapeutics, something which is still some time away. [1] https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/11/26/biden-calls-for-intellectual-property-waivers-covid-vaccines
[2] https://www.reuters.com/business/healthcare-pharmaceuticals/novavax-testing-vaccine-that-targets-new-covid-19-variant-2021-11-26/
[3] https://www.reuters.com/markets/stocks/biontech-starts-work-omicron-specific-vaccine-2021-11-29/
[4] https://www.reuters.com/world/uk/britain-approves-pfizer-covid-19-pill-2021-12-31/

The pandemic is subsiding and less aggressive variants will probably dominate over previous ones. A patent waiver on COVID-19 vaccines doesn't seem to be more urgent as for vaccines for other respiratory diseases. The precedent could have grave consequences.
Unlikely given the number of global population still unvaccinated and the number of countries/people who will require booster doses for vaccines like Sinovac and Coronav
While it could be done with 75% of the membership which equals 123 countries, I think that highly unlikely... around zero.

Nevertheless, neither quick action nor victory can be taken for granted in a body that requires all 164 member countries to be in consent before such measures can pass. Moreover, much will depend upon how much either side is willing to compromise. More than 100 countries backing the waiver say it will help save lives by allowing developing countries to produce COVID-19 vaccines. But a handful of countries, including some hosting major pharmaceutical firms such as Switzerland [also the United Kingdom, Germany & Norway], remain opposed. China in the same meeting described the discussions as circular, with no real progress achieved, according to one of the sources attending. India's delegate said that some members had done everything in their power to avoid meaningful engagement, Opponents said in Monday's discussions that it was not yet clear that a waiver would help remove barriers to vaccine equity such as raw material scarcity and supply chain issues, https://www.reuters.com/business/healthcare-pharmaceuticals/year-after-covid-vaccine-waiver-proposal-wto-talks-are-deadlocked-2021-10-04/ While intellectual property rights are not the only reason for inequitable access to COVID-19 vaccines and therapeutics, they are a significant barrier. Similarly, while a waiver is not the only means to tackle the lack of access to health technologies, it is an essential element in facilitating equitable access. ... there are ample precedents for WTO waivers, including in the area of intellectual property. The 2001 Doha Declaration, for example, was partly implemented through a time limited waiver furthering public health objectives relating to access to medicines. This situation persists despite the vast majority of WTO member states bearing obligations under either the International Covenant on Economic Social and Cultural Rights (ICESCR), which covers the rights to health and science and the principle of non-discrimination, or the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR), which includes the rights to life, equality and the principle of non-discrimination.
On November 8, the International Commission of Jurists published a legal opinion on the proposed waiver. The opinion, which has been endorsed by 140 experts worldwide, argues that member states of the WTO who are also party to either the ICESCR and ICCPR have, at the very least, an obligation to not oppose or obstruct the proposed waiver. Where such states obstruct the proposed waiver, they are acting in defiance of this legally binding obligation. https://www.aljazeera.com/opinions/2021/11/30/rich-countries-must-stop-blocking-the-covid-vaccine-patent-waiver The German government said while they support global vaccine supplies, "the protection of intellectual property is a source of innovation and must remain so in the future."
The government, instead, said production capacity and quality control were the key impediments to widening access to vaccines — not intellectual property rights. While Albert Bourla, CEO of vaccine maker Pfizer said his company was "not at all" in favor of the waivers, European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen said she would be open to discussion on the topic. https://www.dw.com/en/germany-rejects-us-push-to-waive-covid-vaccine-patents/a-57453453
